newsitem.title: CANADA: Toronto stocks end mixed, ignore Wall St. rally.
newsitem.headline: Toronto stocks end mixed, ignore Wall St. rally.

text.p: Toronto stocks ended mixed on Monday as sagging gold shares depressed Canada's biggest stock market while New York equities surged.
The TSE 300 Composite Index slipped 1.35 points to close at 5148.55 in turnover of 70.2 million shares valued at C$783 million ($571 million).
But advancing stocks still outpaced declines 448 to 418 with 293 issues ending flat.
By comparison, the Dow Jones average soared nearly 74 points.
"New York was leading the way, but Toronto was weighed down by the poor performance in golds," said Ira Katzin, an investment advisor for Richardson Greenshields of Canada Ltd.
The TSE's heavyweight gold group sank 256 points as gold prices hit fresh two-month lows during the session. COMEX December gold ended down US$1.60 at US$387.20 an ounce.
Toronto also posted minor losses in communications, conglomerates, base metals and pipelines.
The TSE's nine strong sectors were led by consumer products, transportation, financial services and retailing.
Toronto's strong side was also helped by buoyant North American bond markets.
Canada's 9.00 percent bond due 2001 climbed C$0.75 to C$101.50 to yield 7.863 percent.
* Among weak gold stocks, Barrick Gold Corp. fell 0.90 to 36.30 on 989,000 shares. Placer Dome Inc. dropped 0.90 to 32 on 1.06 million shares.
* Shell Canada Ltd. jumped 1.05 to 46.40 after announcing a major natural gas deal with Houston-based Coral Energy LP.
* Laidlaw Inc. class B gained 0.15 to 13.50 after the waste and transportation giant was upgraded to outperform from market perform by U.S.-based Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette.
* Biovail Corp International was the top gainer, rising 5.50 to 42.50. The stock climbed on a positive article on the biotechnology firm published in the U.S. business magazine Barron's.
